item.title: About
item.description: This is a blogdown website for the hypertidy family of R packages for multi-dimensional and spatial data. Hypertidy is an approach to spatial or multi-dimensional data in R based on the following principles: data sources are best managed with database techniques spatial is not special, user-interfaces, graphics and time-series all involve ‘space’ raster and vector are not naturally distinct, high-dimensional, curvilinear, cell-based rasters, polygon gris and ragged-arrays all cross this boundary ‘mesh-based’ or ‘indexed’ data structures are central, general data types while traditionally “geospatial” structures are domain-specific optimizations simple features left topology behind, resulting in fragmented and inefficient workarounds in the geo-spatial communities R spatial needs better APIs, a rich ecosystem of small, composable software modules tidy data principles are about leveraging databases and database techniques Examples of these principles are seen in these R packages.
